bronze.name: Bronze
bronze.description: The Bronze rank marks the beginning of your coding journey. As a dedicated learner, you're building foundational skills and tackling your first challenges with enthusiasm.

silver.name: Silver
silver.description: Silver-ranked coders demonstrate growing proficiency. You've mastered basic concepts and are now solving more complex problems with increasing confidence and efficiency.

gold.name: Gold
gold.description: Gold rank signifies advanced coding abilities. You consistently deliver solid solutions, understand algorithmic principles, and are ready for more challenging technical puzzles.

platinum.name: Platinum
platinum.description: Platinum coders excel in problem-solving and code quality. Your solutions are not only correct but optimized, showing deep understanding of data structures and algorithms.

diamond.name: Diamond
diamond.description: An elite problem-solver. Diamond-ranked coders consistently deliver high-quality solutions and deep algorithmic knowledge.

master.name: Master
master.description: A true architect of logic and precision. The Master Coder has conquered every challenge with elegance and consistency, demonstrating not just technical skill but creative problem-solving and deep understanding of algorithms.

grandmaster.name: Grandmaster
grandmaster.description: A rare virtuoso — Grandmaster developers lead innovations, solve the hardest problems and inspire the community with creative, reliable solutions.

overview.title: Ranking System
overview.description: The ranking system in LevelUp Journey transforms coding progress into a competitive game experience, where every challenge, solution, and achievement contributes to a player's growth across seven mastery levels, and through consistent participation, problem-solving, and excellence, they climb toward the elite tier of Grandmaster.

intro.simple: Complete challenges, earn points, rank up. Simple.
intro.explanation: Each challenge has maximum points based on difficulty. Your solving time determines what percentage of those points you receive (20% to 100%). All tests must pass to earn points, if any fails you get 0.

rules.title: Scoring Rules Overview
rules.description: Quick guide to how LevelUp Journey translates difficulty, correctness, and time into leaderboard points.

timeBasedScoring.title: Time-Based Scoring System
timeBasedScoring.description: Each difficulty has specific time ranges. They are not global.

difficultyCeiling.title: Difficulty Sets the Ceiling
difficultyCeiling.summary: Every challenge ships with a fixed max score. Difficulty only raises that ceiling — your time determines what you take home.
items: Higher tiers unlock bigger point pools, but also expect longer focus sessions.
Once you know the cap, you can pace your effort to keep the best time window.

correctnessFirst.title: Correctness First
correctnessFirst.summary: Scoring is binary on accuracy. Only fully green test suites move on to time-based math.
items: All tests pass → your time tier decides the percentage.
Any failure → 0 points. No partial credit, but the attempt stays on your history.

timePercentage.title: Time Controls The Percentage
timePercentage.summary: Once correctness is locked, the clock slots you into a payout tier relative to the challenge ceiling.
items: Within grace → 100%. Slight delay → 80%. Moderate → 60%. Slow → 40%. Very late → 20%.
Harder challenges stretch grace periods so advanced problems stay fair.

minimumScore.title: Minimum Guaranteed Score
minimumScore.summary: Passing all tests never feels wasted time. Even the slowest clean solution gives back 20% of the challenge cap.
items: Examples: Easy ≥ 1 pt, Medium ≥ 2 pts, Hard ≥ 4 pts, Expert ≥ 8 pts.
Think of it as effort insurance — correctness always counts.

timeTracking.title: How We Track Time
timeTracking.summary: The timer covers the full build-measure-learn loop, not just the final run button.
items: Start when you create the challenge solution. End on the final submission.
Coding, debugging, and retries all count. Internally we store seconds, but show minutes in the UI.

penalization.title: Penalization
penalization.description: If the student reaches the maximum number of allowed attempts without success, the system may apply a penalty of 25 points to the student's current score.
